Three Mn2O3 with different morphologies and particle sizes were synthesized using MnBDC as precursor. Interestingly, the morphology and size of MnBDC can be easily regulated by changing the reaction solvents slightly. The Mn2O3-L catalyst with large layers and small crystal size exhibited the best catalytic activity for complete oxidation of propane, with T 50 of 266℃ and T90 of 311℃ at the WHSV of 120 L g−1 h−1. The multi-layered structure and small crystal size of Mn2O3-L allowed it to possess a high surface area and more interfacial oxygen defects that facilitated oxygen mobility, improving the catalytic activity. It seems that the large precursor size of MnBDC-L slowed down the decomposition rate of ligands, promoting the formation of large layered structure and small crystal size of Mn2O3-L. This study offers a simple strategy to control the structure and crystal size of Mn2O3 catalysts. Graphical Abstract Keywords Mn2O3 catalysts Morphology control Size control Metal-organic frameworks Propane oxidation Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Volatile organic compounds (VOCs) are significant contributors to human health and environmental damage and typically originate from chemical processes and vehicle exhaust emissions [1,2]. Catalytic oxidation is one of the most commonly used methods for converting VOCs into non-toxic carbon dioxide and water [3–6]. However, the complete oxidation of propane poses significant challenges because of its stable C–H bonds [7]. Therefore, designing highly active catalysts for propane oxidation at low temperatures is of great importance and practical value. Transition-metal oxides, particularly Mn-based oxides, have attracted considerable attention owing to their high activity, good stability, and tunable structure [8–10]. Previous studies have shown that Mn-based oxides with different morphologies exhibit varying catalytic oxidation activities owing to differences in their surface areas, crystal sizes, defect concentrations, and redox abilities [11,12]. For example, layered MnOx has been found to have a larger surface area, more oxygen defects, and faster electron transfer ability, leading to superior catalytic oxidation performance compared to bulk MnOx [13]. However, the relationship between the morphology of Mn-based oxides and their catalytic activity is still debatable, as Mn-oxides with different shapes, such as lamellar/layered, rod-like, hollow, and cubic, have shown excellent catalytic performance [14–17]. Therefore, further research into the relationship between the morphology and size of Mn-based oxides and their catalytic activity is crucial. However, the current synthesis methods for these morphologies are relatively complex, mainly relying on hydrothermal and precipitation methods, which limit the precise control of the morphology and dispersion of active components. Therefore, new synthetic methods are urgently needed. Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are a class of emerging crystalline porous materials formed by the coordination of metal ions and organic ligands [18,19]. Owing to their tunable and porous structures, MOFs have found wide-ranging applications in catalysis, adsorption, separation, and energy storage [20–23]. Recently, significant attention has been dedicated to the thermal decomposition of MOFs in air to obtain their corresponding metal oxides. Our previous studies revealed that MOF-derived oxides exhibit excellent catalytic activity owing to the enhanced dispersion of metal ions and increased number of oxygen defects during the combustion of organic ligands, resulting in smaller crystal sizes and higher defect concentrations [24–26]. However, these studies did not thoroughly investigate the influence of different morphologies on catalytic activity. Considering the morphological tunability of the MOFs, many studies have focused on controlling the morphology of derived oxides by manipulating the morphology of MOFs to establish a correlation between morphology and catalytic activity [27]. Different organic ligands must be selected to achieve controllable morphology. However, the different in situ carbon and oxygen contents in the various ligands may affect the oxygen defect concentrations of the derived oxides [28]. In particular, for Mn-based oxides with multiple crystallographic orientations, a higher content of in situ oxygen in the organic ligands may lead to a crystallographic transition between Mn2O3 and Mn3O4, which hampers the exploration of the relationship between morphology and activity [29]. Therefore, investigating the relationship between the different morphologies of the derived oxides and their catalytic activities under the same ligand conditions is imperative. In addition, although the modulation of the catalytic activity of the derived oxides by controlling the size of the MOFs has been reported [30,31], related studies are limited, and an in-depth investigation of the influence of precursor size on the derived oxides is lacking. In this study, MnBDC samples with different morphologies and sizes were synthesized by manipulating the co-solvent type. Subsequently, thermal decomposition in air yielded Mn2O3 catalysts with distinct morphologies and sizes. In particular, we obtained small layered Mn2O3-S, large layered Mn2O3-L, and rod-cluster-like Mn2O3-C ( Fig. 1). Through comprehensive characterization and experimental investigation, we extensively studied the physicochemical properties of Mn2O3 catalysts with different morphologies and sizes, as well as their catalytic activity in propane oxidation. The reaction mechanism and pathways of propane on Mn2O3 were studied using in-situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS). 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals All chemicals and reagents used in this study were of analytical grade and were used as received without further purification. Mn(NO3)2⋅4 H2O (purity: 99+%) and terephthalic acid (H2BDC, purity: 99+%) were obtained from Aladdin Reagent Co. Ltd. (Shanghai, China). N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF, purity: 99.5+%), ethanol (purity: 99.5+%), and deionized water were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. (Shanghai, China). 2.2 Preparation of MnBDC Different morphologies and sizes of MnBDC were synthesized based on the previous studies with modifications in the choice of co-solvents [32]. For the synthesis of MnBDC with a rod-like cluster (MnBDC-C), a mixture of Mn(NO3)2⋅4 H2O (1.255 g, 5 mmol) and H2BTC (0.833 g, 5 mmol) was dispersed in a 4:1 v/v ratio of DMF to H2O (50 mL) and sonicated for 20 minutes at 25 °C. The resulting solution was then transferred into a 100 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at 100 °C for 24 hours. The white precipitate obtained was filtered, washed with DMF and ethanol three times, and dried at 80 °C for 24 hours. For MnBDC with small bulk (MnBDC-S) and large bulk (MnBDC-L), the solvent composition was adjusted to a 4:1 v/v ratio of DMF to ethanol (50 mL) and a 8:1:1 v/v/v ratio of DMF to H2O to ethanol (50 mL), respectively. 2.3 Preparation of Mn2O3 The synthesized Mn-BDC samples, namely MnBDC-C, MnBDC-S, and MnBDC-L, were calcined in air at 450 °C for 2 hours with a heating rate of 5 °C/min using a muffle furnace. The resulting samples were labeled as Mn2O3-C, Mn2O3-S, and Mn2O3-L for the sake of simplicity in description. 2.4 Catalyst characterization Detailed information regarding these characterization techniques can be found in the Supporting Information (S1). 2.5 Catalytic activity test The catalytic performance of the Mn2O3 catalysts in the total oxidation of C3H8 was evaluated using a continuous-flow tubular fixed-bed reactor system. The experimental conditions and reaction kinetics testing details can be found in the Supporting Information (S2–4). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Physical structure of MnBDC MnBDC samples were synthesized using a solvothermal method, and their morphologies and sizes were controlled by varying the ratio of ethanol (EtOH) and water (H2O) as the co-solvent. A detailed preparation schematic was shown as Fig. 1. First, the morphologies of the different MnBDC precursors were investigated using scanning electron microscopy (SEM). As shown in Fig. S1, using EtOH as the co-solvent, bulk-like particles with a size of approximately 50 μm were formed; these samples were labeled as MnBDC-S. When the co-solvent was changed to the EtOH/H2O mixture, the overall morphology of the sample remained similar to that of MnBDC-S, although the particle size increased to approximately 200 μm; these samples were labeled MnBDC-L. This could be attributed to the formation of EtOH/H2O clusters, which promoted the self-aggregation of the solvent molecules (DMF), thus reducing the mobility of the solvent and slowing the deprotonation rate of H2BDC, ultimately resulting in an increased crystal size [33,34]. When H2O was used as the co-solvent, clusters composed of rod-like materials with a width of approximately 20 μm were formed; these samples were labeled as MnBDC-C. This observation could be attributed to the absence of EtOH, where the introduction of only H2O could accelerate the deprotonation rate of H2BDC, thereby increasing the nucleation rate and inducing rod-like growth in specific directions [35]. The structures of different MnBDC precursors were further characterized using X-ray diffraction (XRD). As shown in Fig. S2, the rod-cluster-like MnBDC-C sample exhibits a structure consistent with that previously reported for MnBDC(H2O)2 (CCDC 195798) [36]. In contrast, the structures of the bulk-like MnBDC-S and MnBDC-L samples were in agreement with those of the previously reported Mn2BDC2DMF2 (CCDC 771997) [37]. This indicates the successful synthesis of three MnBDC crystals with different morphologies and sizes. Notably, both bulk-like samples exhibited pronounced crystallographic facet-selective growth. In particular, MnBDC-L exhibited a clear peak at (030), signifying a heightened level of crystallinity and larger crystal dimensions. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed to determine the appropriate calcination temperature. Fig. S3 shows the weight-loss profiles of the different MnBDC precursors. The initial weight loss at 100–250 °C can be attributed to the removal of H2O, EtOH, and DMF from the MOF pores. At 250–350 °C, significant differences in weight loss were observed among the different MnBDC samples. MnBDC-C showed no significant weight loss, whereas MnBDC-S and MnBDC-L exhibited partial weight loss in this temperature range, which can be attributed to the loss of coordinated DMF. Because the MnBDC-C crystals did not contain coordinated DMF, no such loss was observed, providing further evidence for the aforementioned structures of the three MnBDC crystals. The weight loss at 350–450 °C was attributed to the loss of H2BDC linker. Therefore, a calcination temperature of 450 °C was chosen to achieve the complete decomposition of the organic ligands [32]. 3.2 Physical structure of Mn2O3 First, the morphological characteristics and microstructure of the Mn2O3 catalysts prepared via the thermal decomposition of MnBDC were meticulously investigated using SEM and transmission electron microscopy (TEM), as shown in Fig. 2. After the calcination, the morphologies of the three oxide compounds remained consistent with those of their precursors. In particular, Mn2O3-S (Fig. 2a) and Mn2O3-L (Fig. 2e) exhibited bulk-like structures, with average particle sizes of approximately 50 and 200 μm, respectively. Conversely, Mn2O3-C (Fig. 2i) comprised numerous clusters with rod-like morphology, with a width of approximately 20 μm. Notably, both Mn2O3-S and Mn2O3-L exhibit a layer-by-layer stacking arrangement, which has been previously reported [38]. This layered morphology facilitates the formation of oxygen defects [39,40]. The transmission electron microscope captured only the edge regions of the catalysts owing to their large dimensions (Fig. 2b, f, and g). Remarkably, substantial accumulation of nanocrystals was observed within the catalysts, which contributed to the presence of abundant interfacial defects, thereby enabling efficient lattice oxygen transfer and gas adsorption [41]. Furthermore, high-resolution TEM (HR-TEM) analysis revealed that Mn2O3-S (Fig. 2c) and Mn2O3-L (Fig. 2g) predominantly exhibited the (211) and (400) crystal planes of α-Mn2O3, with corresponding lattice spacing of 0.384 and 0.235 nm, respectively. In contrast, Mn2O3-C (Fig. 2k) primarily exhibited the (211) and (222) crystal planes of α-Mn2O3, with measured lattice spacing of 0.384 and 0.272 nm, respectively. This indicates that all three catalysts consisted of polycrystalline Mn2O3, which is consistent with the subsequent selected-area electron diffraction (SAED) results. The SAED patterns of all three catalysts (Fig. 2d, h, and i) showed diffraction spots and rings, which confirmed their polycrystalline nature. Importantly, Mn2O3-L exhibited more diffraction spots with lower brightness, indicating the presence of a significant number of smaller crystals or lower crystallinity [24]. The abundance of fine crystals contributes to a higher concentration of interfacial defects. The increased number of fine crystals may be attributed to the larger MOF precursors. Previous studies have indicated that MOFs possess poor thermal conductivity, resulting in a significant temperature gradient during thermal treatment, which is known as the heat-transfer resistance phenomenon [42,43]. Consequently, the larger MnBDC-L leads to slower heat transfer and internal thermal decomposition of H2BDC, thereby retaining fragmented organic ligands in the solid state and preventing the aggregation of metal centers. Conversely, a faster decomposition rate results in the rapid combustion of organic ligands, leading to the aggregation of the metal centers. The decomposition temperature range of the BDC linker was summarized based on TGA data to validate the heat transfer resistance in larger MOFs, which provided an indication of the extent of heat and mass transfer resistance within the MOF. Table S1 lists the decomposition temperature ranges of the H2BDC linkers in the three precursors in the order of MnBDC-L (81 °C) > MnBDC-S (66 °C) > MnBDC-C (49 °C), thereby highlighting the higher heat transfer resistance of MnBDC-L and corroborating the aforementioned hypothesis. XRD analysis was conducted to further investigate the phase structure of the three catalysts and the influence of hindered heat transfer on the crystal size. As shown in Fig. 3a, all prepared samples exhibit similar diffraction patterns that match the typical cubic bixbyite α-Mn2O3 (JCPDS 41–1442) structure without any detectable impurities [44]. This was consistent with the HR-TEM results. The characteristic diffraction peaks of α-Mn2O3 are observed at 23.1°, 32.9°, 38.2°, 45.2°, 49.4°, and 55.2°, corresponding to the crystal planes (211), (222), (400), (332), (431), and (440), respectively. The crystal sizes of Mn2O3-C, Mn2O3-L, and Mn2O3-S were calculated using the Scherrer equation and were found to be 19.8, 15.6, and 18.6 nm, respectively. Mn2O3-L exhibited the smallest crystal size, indicating a lower crystallinity and a higher concentration of defects, which are advantageous for gas adsorption and lattice oxygen migration [45]. Smaller crystals typically have more defects, and the concentration of these defects can be confirmed by Raman spectroscopy. As shown in Fig. 3b, all three Mn2O3 samples exhibit Raman activity at 312, 637, and 688 cm−1, corresponding to the out-of-plane bending vibration, asymmetric vibration of the bridging oxygen (Mn–O–Mn), and symmetric stretching vibration, respectively [46,47]. The shift in Raman peaks towards lower frequencies indicates a decrease in the Mn–O bond strength, suggesting the presence of more number of defects [25]. As expected, the defect contents in the three catalysts decreased in the order of Mn2O3-L > Mn2O3-S > Mn2O3-C, further confirming the previous conclusion. Subsequently, N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms and Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) pore size distribution measurements were performed on the three Mn2O3 catalysts, as shown in Fig. 3c and d; the detailed data is summarized in Table 1. Based on the IUPAC classification, all three catalysts exhibit type IV isotherms and H3 hysteresis loops at higher pressures (0.8 ≤ P/P0 ≤ 1.0), indicating the presence of mesoporous structures formed by the stacking of layer-like crystals. This result is in agreement with the TEM results. The BJH pore size distribution curves also showed the dominance of mesopores. In terms of specific surface area, the three catalysts were in the order of Mn2O3-L (57.07 m2/g) > Mn2O3-C (54.53 m2/g) > Mn2O3-S (51.68 m2/g). Mn2O3-L has the largest pore volume and specific surface area, which are favorable for gas migration and adsorption [48]. Typically, the thermal decomposition of MOFs can lead to crystal growth and a reduction in pore volume [24,49]. However, in this case, Mn2O3-L exhibits a significantly larger pore volume (0.43 cm3/g) compared to the other two samples (0.36 cm3/g), which also indirectly verifies the limited thermal decomposition of larger MOFs. 3.3 Chemical properties of Mn2O3 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was conducted to investigate the surface chemical compositions and oxidation states of the three catalysts. As shown in Fig. 4a, the three catalysts contained only Mn, O, and C. By analyzing the Mn3s narrow spectrum (Fig. 4b), the energy difference between the two peaks in the Mn3s curve (ΔE) was calculated to determine the average oxidation state (AOS) of surface Mn ions (Mn AOS=8.956–1.126×ΔE) [50]. The Mn AOS values of the three catalysts were in the order of Mn2O3-L (2.72) < Mn2O3-S (2.80) < Mn2O3-C (2.89), indicating that their valence states are close to the theoretical valence states of Mn2O3. The formation of oxygen defects can result in catalyst reduction, that is, a decrease in the valence state. Hence, the XPS spectra of Mn2p were analyzed to further validate the oxygen defect content (Fig. 4d). The spectra were deconvoluted into three peaks at 640.9, 642.2, and 643.8 eV, corresponding to the Mn2+, Mn3+, and Mn4+ states, respectively [17,51,52]. According to the data in Table 1 and Table S2, the Mn2+/Mn3+ ratio increased in the order of Mn2O3-C < Mn2O3-S < Mn2O3-L, indicating a higher Mn2+/Mn3+ ratio and thus a higher concentration of oxygen defects. Fig. 4c shows the O1s spectra of the three catalysts, with peaks at 529.9 and 531.4 eV corresponding to lattice oxygen (Olatt) and chemisorbed oxygen (Oads) [53,54]. Typically, the quantity of chemisorbed oxygen can be used to evaluate the concentration of oxygen defects [55]. As expected, Mn2O3-L and Mn2O3-C exhibit the highest and lowest oxygen defect concentrations, respectively. H2 temperature-programmed reduction experiments were conducted to assess the influence of the physical structure and surface elemental state of the catalyst on its reducibility; the results are shown in Fig. 5a. All catalysts exhibit two distinct reduction peaks, corresponding to the transformation of Mn2O3 to Mn3O4 and Mn3O4 to MnO phases [56,57]. The reduction temperatures of the different catalysts were in the increasing order of Mn2O3-L (296 and 402 °C) < Mn2O3-S (304 and 411 °C) < Mn2O3-C (316 and 422 °C). This indicates that Mn2O3-L possesses a higher reducibility, enabling it to adsorb more oxygen at lower temperatures. Subsequently, we performed O2 temperature-programmed desorption (O2-TPD) experiments to measure the rate of oxygen migration; the results are shown in Fig. 5b. Generally, oxygen can be distinguished as surface-adsorbed oxygen (<400 °C), surface lattice oxygen (400–600 °C), and bulk lattice oxygen (>600 °C) [17]. Previous studies have reported that surface-adsorbed oxygen and surface lattice oxygen are vital oxygen sources in propane oxidation, and that the migration ability of surface lattice oxygen is positively correlated with catalytic activity [58]. Therefore, we focused on the differences in this temperature range. As shown in Fig. 5c, the large layered Mn2O3-L exhibited the highest concentration of surface lattice oxygen, followed by the small layered Mn2O3-S, whereas the rod-cluster Mn2O3-C showed a minimal release of surface lattice oxygen. This suggests that the surface lattice oxygen in layered Mn2O3 has a higher migration ability, and the presence of abundant defects in large block-like Mn2O3-L accelerates the release of surface lattice oxygen. Based on the aforementioned characterization results, Mn2O3 derived from MnBDC exhibited morphology- and size-dependent physical and chemical properties. First, in terms of morphology, Mn2O3-L and Mn2O3-S, with abundant layered structures, showed easier release of surface lattice oxygen than rod-cluster-like Mn2O3-C. Additionally, they possess more oxygen defects, which facilitate the adsorption of gas-phase oxygen molecules by the catalyst and accelerate the migration of lattice oxygen, thereby enhancing the low-temperature oxidation ability of the catalyst. Next, a comparison was made between the differently sized layered Mn2O3, which revealed that MnBDC-L exhibits a larger size than MnBDC-S. This larger size helps to reduce heat transfer and suppress the decomposition of organic ligands, thereby inhibiting the agglomeration of metal centers. Consequently, Mn2O3-L has a smaller crystal size, larger surface area, higher defect concentration, and better redox performance. 3.4 Catalytic activity According to the activity data for the complete oxidation of propane under the condition of WHSV=120 L g−1 h−1 (shown in Fig. 6a and Table 2), the activities of the three catalysts are in the order of Mn2O3-L (T10=213 ℃, T50=266 ℃, T90=311 ℃) > Mn2O3-S (T10=228 ℃, T50=280 ℃, T90=323 ℃) > Mn2O3-C (T10=235 ℃, T50=294 ℃, T90=368 ℃). This indicates a close correlation between the catalyst activity and its morphology and size. Fig. S4 shows the CO2 yield of the three catalysts. Although it exhibits a slight lag compared to the propane conversion curve, a strong correlation was observed overall, signifying the complete oxidation of propane to CO2 and H2O. The reaction rates are presented in Fig. 6b to provide a clearer depiction of the differences in propane catalytic activity among the three catalysts at 220 and 260 °C. In the early stage of the reaction (220 ℃), the propane reaction rate of Mn2O3-L was two and four times those of Mn2O3-S and Mn2O3-C, respectively. Even as the temperature increased (260 ℃), Mn2O3-L continued to exhibit significantly higher reaction rates compared to the other two catalysts. This demonstrated the superior catalytic performance of Mn2O3-L. Considering the impact of specific surface area on the rate of catalytic reactions, the specific reaction rates of three catalysts were calculated, as shown in Fig. S5. The sequence of catalysts specific reaction rates is arranged as Mn2O3-L > Mn2O3-S > Mn2O3-C. Specifically, at 220℃, the specific reaction rates for the three catalysts were 0.52, 1.04, and 1.80 ×10−8 mol m−2 s−1, respectively, consistent with the outcomes of catalytic activity. The turnover frequencies (TOF) of the three catalysts at 220℃, as demonstrated in Table 2, exhibit a correlation with their catalytic activities, among which Mn2O3-L possesses the highest TOF value of 5.27 ×10−5 s−1. This further signifies the high catalytic efficiency of the Mn sites on Mn2O3-L. As shown in Fig. 6c, the apparent activation energies were fitted using the Arrhenius equation to investigate the reaction rate of propane further. All curves exhibited good linearity. The apparent activation energies were in the order Mn2O3-L < Mn2O3-S < Mn2O3-C, where a lower activation energy corresponds to easier reaction, further confirming the ranking of propane catalytic activity among the three catalysts. Fig. 6d shows the catalytic activity of Mn2O3-L at different propane weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) values in order to evaluate the catalyst performance at different WHSV values and compare it with the activities reported in the literature. Evidently, the activity of the catalyst significantly improved at lower WHSV values and achieved near-complete oxidation of propane at a high WHSV (WHSV=240 L g−1 h−1). Compared with the catalysts reported in the literature (Table S3), the Mn2O3 catalyst derived from MnBDC exhibited excellent performance, particularly under high propane concentrations and large WHSV values. Therefore, large layered Mn2O3-L is comparable to supported noble metals and composite oxide catalysts. Stability is an important criterion for evaluating the catalyst performance. Fig. 6e presents the thermal stability data of Mn2O3-L at 300 °C and WHSV=120 L g−1 h−1, where the propane conversion rate remains at approximately 83 % without significant decrease. The cycling performance of the catalysts was also validated. As shown in Fig. 6f, after five cycles, the reaction rate of Mn2O3-L decreases from 98.1 % to 91.9 % at 340 °C, which may be related to carbon poisoning. Our previous study shows the carbon poisoning can be eliminated by oxygen combustion [25]. It is worth noting that the reaction of propane oxidation on the catalysts can be still completed after increasing the temperature, suggesting the superior stability of the catalysts. 3.5 Catalytic reaction mechanism DRIFTS was employed to identify the surface chemical species of the catalyst to gain deeper insight into the catalytic reaction of propane with MOF-derived Mn2O3. The experiment recorded all the functional group frequencies, which are summarized in Table S4. Fig. 7a shows propane adsorption on Mn2O3 in the absence of oxygen. The vibrational peaks observed at 2965, 2906, 2872, and 1384 cm−1 are attributed to υas(CH3), υas(CH2), υs(CH3), and δs(CH3), respectively, indicating the gas-phase adsorption of propane [53,59,60]. Vibration peaks related to υs(CC) and δs(CH) are observed at 1627 and 1468 cm−1, respectively, suggesting the rapid dehydrogenation of propane to propene upon adsorption on the catalyst surface [61]. Vibrational peaks in the proximity of 1726, 1172, and 1072 cm−1 are assigned to υs(CO) of acetone species, υas(C–O–C) of the ester group, and υs(C–O–C) [7,62]. Vibrational peaks at 1584, 1440, 1351, and 1272 cm−1 are attributed to υas(COO) of formate and acetate, υas(CH3COO), υs(COO), and υs(CH3COO), respectively [9,58,63]. The presence of these oxygen intermediates suggests further oxidation reactions of propene on the catalyst surface, even at low temperatures of 50 °C. Over time, the vibrational peaks of propane and propene gradually intensified, indicating the adsorption and dehydrogenation of propane. However, no significant increase was observed in the peaks corresponding to the oxygen intermediates, indicating a limitation in the complete oxidation of propane. Subsequently, DRIFTS spectra of the samples were measured at 50–300 °C. As shown in Fig. 7b, with increasing temperature, the vibrational peaks of propane gradually weakened, whereas a series of signals from the oxygen intermediates gradually strengthened, suggesting sustained oxidation reactions of propane, even under inert gas conditions. Combined with the O2-TPD results, the catalyst surface is confirmed to contain a significant amount of surface-adsorbed oxygen species that can serve as reactive oxygen species (ROS) for propane oxidation by reacting with the adsorbed propane to form a series of oxygen-containing intermediates. In an oxygen-free environment, the surface-adsorbed oxygen species cannot be replenished by gaseous oxygen, and a lower temperature makes it difficult to activate the surface lattice oxygen. Consequently, only a limited number of oxygen-containing intermediates were generated. However, with increasing temperature, the bond energy of Mn–O decreases, making the surface lattice oxygen more easily activated to form active surface lattice oxygen. This active surface lattice oxygen can then participate as ROS in the oxidation of propane [64]. Notably, in catalysts featuring numerous defects, the transfer and activation of surface lattice oxygen are accelerated, thereby facilitating the profound involvement of propane in oxidation reactions. Consequently, the ROS on Mn2O3-L mainly emanate from two pathways: (1) the adsorption of gaseous oxygen at oxygen vacancies, leading to surface-adsorbed oxygen species, and (2) the activation of surface lattice oxygen to form active surface lattice oxygen. To verify the role of gaseous oxygen replenishment, adsorption tests were conducted under oxygenated conditions by introducing oxygen into the reaction chambers. Fig. 7c shows that the introduction of oxygen resulted in slight shifts but no significant changes in the vibrational peaks of propane and the intermediate products, indicating that the reaction pathway remained unchanged. To observe the effects more clearly, Fig. 7d shows the adsorption curves of propane under oxygen- and oxygen-free conditions for 25 min. Evidently, the introduction of oxygen did not increase the adsorption of propane. However, a sharp increase is observed in the signals from the intermediate products, indicating that the introduction of oxygen promotes the generation of oxygen-containing intermediates, that is, the replenishment effect of gaseous oxygen on the surface-adsorbed oxygen species. Subsequently, temperature-programmed reactions were conducted under oxygenated conditions. With increasing temperature, the trends are similar to those observed under oxygen-free conditions (Fig. 7e). However, at 350 °C, the vibrational peaks of the adsorbed propane under oxygen conditions were weaker compared to the those under oxygen-free conditions (Fig. 7f), indicating the rapid oxidation of a large amount of propane. Additionally, the vibrational peaks of the oxygen-containing intermediates were weaker, suggesting rapid deep oxidation of the oxygen-containing intermediates. According to the Mars–van Krevelen mechanism, the consumption of surface lattice oxygen leads to the formation of oxygen vacancies [65]. The presence of these oxygen vacancies accelerates the flow of surface lattice oxygen and the adsorption of gaseous oxygen, further enhancing the deep oxidation of propane. The surface lattice oxygen can also be replenished by the adsorption of gaseous oxygen. In summary, gaseous oxygen is crucial in the complete oxidation of propane by replenishing both the surface-adsorbed oxygen species and surface lattice oxygen. Based on these results, we propose a mechanism for the complete oxidation of propane on polycrystalline Mn2O3 ( Fig. 8). First, propane is adsorbed onto the Mn2O3 surface, followed by dehydrogenation to form propene. Subsequently, propene reacts with the active surface oxygen on the catalyst to generate a series of oxygen-containing intermediates such as ketones, esters, acetates, and formates. Finally, under the action of surface-active oxygen, these intermediates are mineralized into CO2 and H2O. ROS mainly originate from the adsorption of gaseous oxygen and the activation of surface lattice oxygen. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, we have successfully synthesized three different morphologies and sizes of Mn2O3 catalysts, excluding the influence of organic ligands, and investigated their physicochemical properties and catalytic activity. Our experimental results demonstrate that the morphology and size of MnBDC have a significant effect on the activity of the derived oxide catalyst. Notably, Mn2O3-L exhibits the highest catalytic activity for the complete oxidation of propane, achieving complete conversion under the conditions of 1 % propane concentration and a high gas hourly space velocity of 120 L g−1 h−1. This enhanced activity can be attributed to the layered morphology of Mn2O3-L, which helps increase oxygen defects and promote the flow of lattice oxygen on the surface. Additionally, the larger MOFs size limits the decomposition rate of the organic ligands, restraining crystal growth and resulting in more defects and a higher specific surface area. Furthermore, through DRIFTS experiments, we have elucidated the reaction pathway of propane on the Mn2O3 catalysts’ surfaces. Initially, propane undergoes dehydrogenation to form propene. Subsequently, propene reacts with the active surface oxygen to generate various oxygen-containing intermediates, including ketones, esters, acetates, and formates. Finally, these intermediates are further mineralized to carbon dioxide and water with the assistance of surface active oxygen. This study highlights the advantages of layered morphology in the catalytic oxidation of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) and proposes a strategy to enhance the oxygen defect concentration of derived oxides by increasing the size of the MOFs precursor. These findings are of great significance for further exploration and research on catalyst materials with excellent catalytic performance in this field. coredata.dc:description: Three Mn2O3 with different morphologies and particle sizes were synthesized using MnBDC as precursor. Interestingly, the morphology and size of MnBDC can be easily regulated by changing the reaction solvents slightly. The Mn2O3-L catalyst with large layers and small crystal size exhibited the best catalytic activity for complete oxidation of propane, with T 50 of 266℃ and T90 of 311℃ at the WHSV of 120 L g−1 h−1. The multi-layered structure and small crystal size of Mn2O3-L allowed it to possess a high surface area and more interfacial oxygen defects that facilitated oxygen mobility, improving the catalytic activity. It seems that the large precursor size of MnBDC-L slowed down the decomposition rate of ligands, promoting the formation of large layered structure and small crystal size of Mn2O3-L. This study offers a simple strategy to control the structure and crystal size of Mn2O3 catalysts.
